headline: Easy Chorizo Street Tacos
description: Easy chorizo tacos made with crumbled chorizo quickly cooked with chipotle peppers, then topped with chopped cilantro and onion in a warm tortilla.

video.name: How to Make Easy Chorizo Street Tacos

name: Easy Chorizo Street Tacos
recipeIngredient: 1 chorizo sausage link, casing removed and meat crumbled
2 tablespoons chipotle peppers in adobo sauce
2 tablespoons chopped onion, or to taste
2 tablespoons chopped fresh cilantro, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Combine crumbled chorizo and chipotle peppers in adobo sauce in a bowl.
Heat a skillet over medium-high heat; add chorizo mixture and cook until crisp, 5 to 7 minutes. Transfer to a plate, reserving grease in the skillet.
Heat tortillas in reserved grease in the skillet over medium heat until warmed, 1 to 2 minutes per side. Stack 2 tortillas for each taco, then fill with chorizo, onion, and cilantro.

review.reviewBody: Warning; this is fairly spicy! However, deliciously simple and easy and quick to make for those who can stand the kick. So convenient for an easy weeknight meal. Very little prep and cook time.

I'm so glad I found this recipe! Since finding this recipe 6 months ago, this has become a staple that I make at least once (sometimes twice) a week. My husband and I both love it. I only make a couple of changes. We love things extra extra spicy, so I add 5 tablespoons of chipotle in adobo sauce. I also top the tacos with shredded mexican cheese, in addition to the cilantro and onion. And instead of frying up tortillas, I just use storebought hard taco shells, the nacho cheese flavored ones. Sooo good! The nacho cheese flavor blends so nicely with the spicy chorizo meat. There have been a few times I've made this that I haven't been able to find chorizo meat. It doesn't taste quite as good, but I've found that sweet italian sausage meat works well enough in a pinch.
Super in three ways: (1) easy; (2) tasty; (3) spicy. Can't wait to make this again.
Not a fan. Sorry! Warming the tortillas in the leftover grease was very off putting.
waaay too spicy!!!

These are easy and delicious! They are a little spicy but still very good! Made as written! To “mild” it down a little, took Mrs WyoFish tips on making a slaw; 1/4c lime juice, TBLS brown sugar, tsp Siracha, 1/4 tsp cumin, dash of garlic powder. Let sit in half bag pre-chopped slaw 20+ minutes before starting. Wish I had avocado! Would absolutely make again! Thank you!!

I mixed 2 of the 9oz Beef Chorizo tubes along with 1 lb package of ground beef. Only used 1 Tbsp of the Adobo sauce and it was still pretty spicy. I would only do 1/2 Tbsp if you want it mild. Cooking the tortillas in the leftover grease was a huge hit for the flavor! This made a lot of meat, enough for a family dinner and leftovers for the next day. Would definitely make this again!!

Good recipe! As is, it is VERY hot/spicy! If you're not used to spicy foods, I recommend 1/2 tablespoon of sour cream per taco; this will help cool spices down and make it more enjoyable. I also added Mexican cheese blend and 1 teaspoon of lime juice to each taco!
Love this recipe. So simple and delicious.
Perfect, reminds me of the nearby taco truck.

No need to mix the peppers and the chorizo in a bowl beforehand. Just brown the chorizo in the pan, then add the peppers and sauce for an additional minute. Quite spicy! If you're not sure, start with half the amount of pepper and adobo.
I get these from my favorite restaurant. This recipe came very close. I squeeze some fresh lime on them when plating as well as a canned enchilada sauce that I doctor up.
I had this before and love it! I can't wait to make this tacos with a couple of beers!
Very simple and easy recipe that is absolutely delicious!
Super simple, super tasty. Leftover ingredients are a godsend after coming home from a night out on the town!
Made a fresh tomato salsa to go with it. Great recipe and very simple

I loved this recipe! It was fast to make and very tasty. I wanted to stretch the recipe so added 8 oz of ground sirloin to 14 oz of chorizo. It wasn't too spicy with the added hamburger, in fact I'd probably add less hamburger next time to keep it spicy. Really liked the tortillas fried in chorizo fat! Also added pepperjack cheese. Definitely will make it again.
Excellent, especially a nice appetizer!
Amazing. I could eat just the chorizo/chipotle/adobo without any of the toppings it’s so good. Added avocado slice, lime, and chihuahua cheese
Added 1/2 lb ground beef to calm the chorizo flavor for my son... so good!!

Woo hoo zippy! Living in the Dallas area now briefly I was introduced to street tacos by an impromptu taco stand set up outside a Boot Barn. OMG the best taco I ever had. Just like this, with cilantro, and onion, but they provided lime wedges as well and the hottest taco sauce I've ever witnessed. This recipe does not need more hot. Just dab a little Mexican crema (like a creme fraiche) over these tacos to take the heat down a bit if you want. Glorious.
I made my own adobo sauce using my bullet, and drizzled a little bit of guacamole salsa on top. Turned out great!

These are totally authentic except one thing: the heat is about twice what I typically experience in NY, Brooklyn, and Queens. I reduced the peppers in adobo to 1/4 of the recommended amount, and they are totally perfect!!!
I made this for Sunday Family Lunch and everyone loved them. Plus this was so easy and quick.
Delicieux
it was pretty good but a little spicy
Fantastic recipe! A new family favorite. I changed absolutely nothing on this recipe. Also very easy to make.

These were AMAZE. I devoured them within minutes of plating them... But of course, me being me, I added my own touches: 1) I made a nice slaw to go with, for added color (as my plates are not as colorful as the ones in the main picture for this recipe) and honestly it goes well with any taco or tostada recipe... red cabbage, sliced radishes, cilantro + juice of 1 lime & 1 tablespoon-ish brown sugar... usually I add siracha, 2 or so garlic cloves, cumin, coriander, etc to this slaw—but as the main dish was already anticipated to be pretty spicy, I stopped at the brown sugar. Serve on top of the tacos or on the side. 2) Lime-sour cream to top it all off. Again, this goes well with any taco recipe; simply take juice of 1 lime and add sour cream and fresh cracked pepper. Add as much as you want to get it to a consistency you like... this makes a really delightfully creamy appeal to counter the spiciness.

This was great! We made this with pork butt and chorizo because my daughter doesn't like the texture of ground meat, I'm glad I did because it would have been too spicy. We also added cheese because cheese.
The second time I made this I cooked everything together in an instapot and added black beans and it was the bomb!
great flavor but too spicy for us!!
I loved these tacos! But then again, I love anything and everything with Mexican Chorizo. I like the concept of dipping the tortilla in the chorizo grease. A little messy but delicious.
